BART.label: FALSE
BART.Justification para:
Biden said that from the start, the Second Amendment "limited the type of people who could own a gun and what type of weapon you could own."

BART.label: FALSE
BART.Justification para:
DeSantis said Biden has driven the current coronavirus surge because he "imported more virus from around the world by having a wide open southern border."
The available evidence shows that coronavirus hot spots tend to be clustered either far from the border or on the water, whereas the entire land border with Mexico has fairly low rates. The hotspot locations tend to correlate with low rates of vaccination among the public.

BART.label: TRUE
BART.Justification para:
Udall said that currently, the intelligence community "can collect business records on law-abiding Americans who have no connection to terrorism."
Recent news reports, which prompted acknowledgements by U.S. officials, confirm that intelligence agencies have been gathering a vast amount of phone metadata, which they argue falls under the category of business records. This metadata can be "collected" -- as Udall phrased it -- though it’s important to note that this data cannot be utilized directly in an investigation until a more stringent legal standard is met.
Meanwhile, common sense tells us that millions of Americans who are having their metadata collected are not involved in terrorism, further bolstering Udall’s claim.
Because this program was approved by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, it is, in a de facto sense, legal. That doesn’t mean the program wouldn’t be vulnerable to court challenges in the future, but until that happens, we rate the statement True.

flan-t5.input_text: "The reality" in Texas is that "you’re flying helicopters, using fossil fuels, to put oil on wind turbines to defrost them.”
flan-t5.label: FALSE
flan-t5.Justification para:
Logan said, "The reality is here (in Texas) that you’re flying helicopters using fossil fuels to put oil on wind turbines to defrost them."
Logan’s claim resembled debunked claims that said an image showed a helicopter spraying chemicals on a wind turbine in Texas. The image was actually taken years ago in Sweden.
Aircraft-based sprays are one way to manually defrost turbines that haven’t been winterized, but experts we consulted said they hadn’t heard of that practice being used in Texas. One company that runs several wind farms in Texas said it isn’t using helicopters to spray oil on its turbines.
The burden of proof is on the speaker, and Logan provided none. We rate her claim False.

flan-t5.claim: Currently, the intelligence community "can collect business records on law-abiding Americans who have no connection to terrorism."
flan-t5.when_where: stated on June 9, 2013 in a Senate speech rebroadcast on ABC's "This Week":
flan-t5.questions-implied: Can these records be used as evidence of a connection to terrorism?
flan-t5.input_text: Currently, the intelligence community "can collect business records on law-abiding Americans who have no connection to terrorism."
flan-t5.label: TRUE
flan-t5.Justification para:
Udall said that currently, the intelligence community "can collect business records on law-abiding Americans who have no connection to terrorism."
Recent news reports, which prompted acknowledgements by U.S. officials, confirm that intelligence agencies have been gathering a vast amount of phone metadata, which they argue falls under the category of business records. This metadata can be "collected" -- as Udall phrased it -- though it’s important to note that this data cannot be utilized directly in an investigation until a more stringent legal standard is met.
Meanwhile, common sense tells us that millions of Americans who are having their metadata collected are not involved in terrorism, further bolstering Udall’s claim.
Because this program was approved by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, it is, in a de facto sense, legal. That doesn’t mean the program wouldn’t be vulnerable to court challenges in the future, but until that happens, we rate the statement True.

T5.claim: "The Second Amendment, from the day it was passed, limited the type of people who could own a gun and what type of weapon you could own.”

T5.input_text: "The Second Amendment, from the day it was passed, limited the type of people who could own a gun and what type of weapon you could own.”
T5.label: FALSE
T5.Justification para:
Biden said that from the start, the Second Amendment "limited the type of people who could own a gun and what type of weapon you could own."
The Second Amendment limited government power, not the rights of individuals. Laws at the time that limited firearm ownership were primarily racist, aimed at controlling Black people and Native Americans.
Broadly, gun regulation came decades after passage of the Second Amendment when gun technology changed. The first national gun regulation law did not rely on the Second Amendment.
We rate Biden’s claim False.

T5.claim: Currently, the intelligence community "can collect business records on law-abiding Americans who have no connection to terrorism."

T5.questions-implied: Can these records be used as evidence of a connection to terrorism?
T5.input_text: Currently, the intelligence community "can collect business records on law-abiding Americans who have no connection to terrorism."
T5.label: TRUE
T5.Justification para:
Udall said that currently, the intelligence community "can collect business records on law-abiding Americans who have no connection to terrorism."
Recent news reports, which prompted acknowledgements by U.S. officials, confirm that intelligence agencies have been gathering a vast amount of phone metadata, which they argue falls under the category of business records. This metadata can be "collected" -- as Udall phrased it -- though it’s important to note that this data cannot be utilized directly in an investigation until a more stringent legal standard is met.
Meanwhile, common sense tells us that millions of Americans who are having their metadata collected are not involved in terrorism, further bolstering Udall’s claim.
Because this program was approved by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, it is, in a de facto sense, legal. That doesn’t mean the program wouldn’t be vulnerable to court challenges in the future, but until that happens, we rate the statement True.

mistral.input_text: Says Donald Trump got “exposed for raping a 13-year-old" in retaliation for law enforcement officers “killing black people.”
mistral.label: FALSE
mistral.Justification para:
A recent Facebook post says President Donald Trump was "exposed for raping a 13-year-old" in retaliation for law enforcement officers "killing black people."
A 2016 lawsuit accused Trump, then a candidate for president, of raping a minor, but no evidence was put forth before the case was dropped. There’s also no evidence that the allegation was tied to law enforcement officer-involved deaths of African-Americans. We rate this Facebook post False.

The girls (14-16) are standing there with no clothes on."
The post distorts remarks Trump made when speaking with radio show host Howard Stern in 2005. At the time, Trump was talking about his behavior during the Miss Universe and Miss USA pageants, where all contestants are over the age of 18.
Five former Miss Teen USA contestants have accused Trump of walking into the dressing room when girls were changing during the 1997 pageant. But there is no evidence he said this quote about the Miss Teen USA pageant.
We rate this claim False.

mistral.claim: "The reality" in Texas is that "you’re flying helicopters, using fossil fuels, to put oil on wind turbines to defrost them.”
mistral.when_where: stated on February 19, 2021 in a TV segment:
mistral.questions-implied:
Are fossil fuels used to defrost wind turbines anywhere? 
Are helicopters being used to put oil on wind turbines?
mistral.input_text: "The reality" in Texas is that "you’re flying helicopters, using fossil fuels, to put oil on wind turbines to defrost them.”
mistral.label: FALSE
mistral.Justification para:
Logan said, "The reality is here (in Texas) that you’re flying helicopters using fossil fuels to put oil on wind turbines to defrost them."
Logan’s claim resembled debunked claims that said an image showed a helicopter spraying chemicals on a wind turbine in Texas. The image was actually taken years ago in Sweden.
Aircraft-based sprays are one way to manually defrost turbines that haven’t been winterized, but experts we consulted said they hadn’t heard of that practice being used in Texas. One company that runs several wind farms in Texas said it isn’t using helicopters to spray oil on its turbines.
The burden of proof is on the speaker, and Logan provided none. We rate her claim False.
mistral.url:
Q1: Are any companies in Texas using oil to defrost wind turbines in Texas?
Q2: Are fossil fuels used to defrost wind turbines anywhere?
Q3: Are helicopters being used to put oil on wind turbines?
mistral.questions-literal: Are any companies in Texas using oil to defrost wind turbines in Texas?
mistral.questions-all:
Are any companies in Texas using oil to defrost wind turbines in Texas?
Are fossil fuels used to defrost wind turbines anywhere? 
Are helicopters being used to put oil on wind turbines?
pred: Is it common practice in Texas to use helicopters with fossil fuels to defrost wind turbines?

mistral.claim: Under Joe Biden’s policy, immigrants in the country illegally “get welfare benefits. United States citizens don't get what they're looking to give illegal immigrants.”
mistral.when_where: stated on July 14, 2020 in a White House speech:
mistral.questions-implied:
Are illegal immigrants in the U.S. allowed to pay for welfare benefits of any kind?
Would welfare benefits for legal immigrants change under the policy?
mistral.input_text: Under Joe Biden’s policy, immigrants in the country illegally “get welfare benefits. United States citizens don't get what they're looking to give illegal immigrants.”
mistral.label: FALSE
mistral.Justification para:
Trump said Biden wants to sign up immigrants illegally in the country for welfare and "United States citizens don't get what they're looking to give illegal immigrants."
A task force recommended that Biden extend health care coverage to immigrants illegally in the country by allowing them to purchase insurance through the Affordable Care Act marketplace, and allowing them to have health care coverage during a pandemic. Being allowed to buy health insurance isn’t the same as getting welfare.
The group also recommended easing federal benefits restrictions on immigrants — but for those lawfully present in the United States. The recommendations do not deny benefits to U.S. citizens or give immigrants illegally in the country an upper hand.
Trump’s claim is inaccurate. We rate it False.
mistral.url:
Q1: Are illegal immigrants in the U.S. allowed to pay for welfare benefits of any kind?
Q2: Are illegal immigrants in the U.S. automatically granted welfare benefits?
Q3: Would Joe Biden's policy grant illegal immigrants welfare benefits?
Q4: Would welfare benefits for legal immigrants change under the policy?
mistral.questions-literal:
Are illegal immigrants in the U.S. automatically granted welfare benefits?
Would Joe Biden's policy grant illegal immigrants welfare benefits?
mistral.questions-all:
Are illegal immigrants in the U.S. automatically granted welfare benefits?
Would Joe Biden's policy grant illegal immigrants welfare benefits?
"Are illegal immigrants in the U.S. allowed to pay for welfare benefits of any kind?
Would welfare benefits for legal immigrants change under the policy?"

mistral.claim: "Polls show that 96 percent of New Jerseyans – and 95 percent of gun households in the state – support expanding background checks to keep guns away from those who shouldn’t have them."
mistral.when_where: stated on August 12, 2013 in an opinion column on NJ.com:
mistral.input_text: "Polls show that 96 percent of New Jerseyans – and 95 percent of gun households in the state – support expanding background checks to keep guns away from those who shouldn’t have them."
mistral.label: TRUE
mistral.Justification para:
Kelly said in an opinion column, ""Polls show that 96 percent of New Jerseyans – and 95 percent of gun households in the state – support expanding background checks to keep guns away from those who shouldn’t have them."
Kelly was referring to a Quinnipiac University Polling Institute poll from January, with findings that match numbers he cited. The poll’s question specifically referenced guns bought at gun shows, and Kelly’s spokeswoman confirmed that his statement in his column referred to such purchases.
We rate Kelly’s claim True.
To comment on this story, go toNJ.com.

mistral.claim: Says Joe Biden has driven the current coronavirus surge because he “imported more virus from around the world by having a wide open southern border.”
mistral.when_where: stated on August 4, 2021 in a press conference:
mistral.questions-implied: Compared to Trump, is the southern border far more open to immigration under Joe Biden?
mistral.input_text: Says Joe Biden has driven the current coronavirus surge because he “imported more virus from around the world by having a wide open southern border.”
mistral.label: FALSE
mistral.Justification para:
DeSantis said Biden has driven the current coronavirus surge because he "imported more virus from around the world by having a wide open southern border."
The available evidence shows that coronavirus hot spots tend to be clustered either far from the border or on the water, whereas the entire land border with Mexico has fairly low rates. The hotspot locations tend to correlate with low rates of vaccination among the public.
In addition, the U.S. does not have a "wide open" border. Most people who are encountered are turned away under a Trump-era policy that Biden continued.
We rate the statement False.
mistral.url:
Q1: Do the coronavirus hostspots correlate with immigration along the southern border?
Q2: Is the southern U.S. border wide open for immigration?
Q3: Compared to Trump, is our southern border far more open to immigration under Joe Biden?

mistral.claim: Currently, the intelligence community "can collect business records on law-abiding Americans who have no connection to terrorism."
mistral.when_where: stated on June 9, 2013 in a Senate speech rebroadcast on ABC's "This Week":
mistral.questions-implied: Can these records be used as evidence of a connection to terrorism?
mistral.input_text: Currently, the intelligence community "can collect business records on law-abiding Americans who have no connection to terrorism."
mistral.label: TRUE
mistral.Justification para:
Udall said that currently, the intelligence community "can collect business records on law-abiding Americans who have no connection to terrorism."
Recent news reports, which prompted acknowledgements by U.S. officials, confirm that intelligence agencies have been gathering a vast amount of phone metadata, which they argue falls under the category of business records. This metadata can be "collected" -- as Udall phrased it -- though it’s important to note that this data cannot be utilized directly in an investigation until a more stringent legal standard is met.
Meanwhile, common sense tells us that millions of Americans who are having their metadata collected are not involved in terrorism, further bolstering Udall’s claim.
Because this program was approved by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, it is, in a de facto sense, legal. That doesn’t mean the program wouldn’t be vulnerable to court challenges in the future, but until that happens, we rate the statement True.
mistral.url:
Q1: Have intelligence agencies been collecting records from U.S. citizens?
Q2: Can these records be used as evidence of a connection to terrorism?
Q3: Are U.S. citizens that are having their records collected have connections to terrorism?
mistral.questions-literal:
Have intelligence agencies been collecting records from U.S. citizens?
Are U.S. citizens that are having their records collected have connections to terrorism?
mistral.questions-all:
Have intelligence agencies been collecting records from U.S. citizens?
Are U.S. citizens that are having their records collected have connections to terrorism?
Can these records be used as evidence of a connection to terrorism?
pred: Can the intelligence community collect business records of law-abiding Americans not connected to terrorism?
